security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown guidance for git commit best practices. All 70 static findings are false positives - the scanner misinterpreted documentation examples as executable code. SKILL.md contains no shell execution, network calls, or file system operations beyond its own static content. The backticks and shell syntax are markdown code blocks showing examples, not actual commands being executed.

content.value_statement: Manual git commit creation lacks consistency and structure. This skill enforces Conventional Commits with emoji prefixes for clear, standardized commit messages that improve team collaboration and changelog generation.
actual_capabilities: Creates Conventional Commits with emoji prefixes (feat, fix, refactor, etc)
Enforces feature-unit commits instead of file-by-file commits
Validates commit message format with character limits
Provides result-oriented commit messages in imperative mood
Supports multi-line commit messages with detailed explanations
Includes breaking changes syntax and review fix commits
limitations: Does not execute git commands automatically
Does not create or modify files in the repository
Does not integrate with git hosting platforms
Requires user to run git commit command manually

best_practices: Always review staged changes before committing to ensure all related files are included
Write commit messages in imperative mood (add, not added or adding)
Group related changes into feature units rather than committing per file
anti_patterns: Creating commits that list development process instead of final results
Committing files individually when they belong to the same feature
Using vague commit subjects like "update code" or "fix stuff"

faq.question: Does this skill run git commit automatically?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and format rules. You run the git commit command yourself.

faq.question: What is Conventional Commits format?
faq.answer: A structured format with emoji, type, scope, and subject that makes commits easier to understand.

faq.question: Can I use this with any git hosting platform?
faq.answer: Yes, Conventional Commits works with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and any platform that reads git history.

faq.question: Is my commit data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No, this is a prompt-based skill. Commit data stays local and is only processed by git on your machine.

faq.question: Why use emoji prefixes?
faq.answer: Emoji prefixes make commit history scannable. Team members can quickly identify the type of change.

faq.question: How does this differ from other commit tools?
faq.answer: This skill enforces result-oriented messages and feature-unit commits rather than process-oriented commits.
